title: THELPOUSA
content:
THELPOUSA (Thelpusa) was the Naiad-nymph of the spring, well or fountain of the town of Thelpousa in Arkadia
        (southern Greece). She was the daughter of the local river-god Ladon.

TELPHUâ€²SA (Telphoussa or Telphousa). 1. A daughter of Ladon, a nymph from whom the town of Telphusa in
        Arcadia derived its name. (Steph. Byz. s. v.) 2. Telphussaea or Tilphussaea occurs as a surname of
        Demeter Erinnys, derived from a town Telphussion. (Schol. ad Soph. Antig. 117; Callim. Fragm.
          207, ed. Bentley.)

Source: Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology.

Pausanias, Description of Greece 8. 25. 2 (trans. Jones) (Greek travelogue C2nd A.D.)
          :
        "[The town of Thelpousa (Thelpusa) in Arkadia] was named after Thelpousa, a Nymphe, and that she was a
        daughter of Ladon."

A complete bibliography of the translations quoted on this page.
